newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Northeast spot power firms amid nuke outages.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Northeast spot power firms amid nuke outages.

text.p: Spot electricity values in the northeast U.S. firmed Monday amid ongoing outages of two nuclear power plants in the region, market sources said.
New York Power Authority's 780 megawatt (MW) Fitzpatrick 1 nuclear unit in Scriba, N.Y., was still shut after being expected to restart this past weekend after being tripped off line a week ago.
Boston Edison Co's 670 MW Pilgrim plant in Plymouth, Mass., was scheduled to return to service later this week to correct problems with a set of its heat exchangers.

In the New York Power Pool (NYPP), non-firm electricity for peak load hours on Tuesday was assessed near $20.00 in the western part of the state and $22.00 in the eastern part, up from Friday's $18.00 and $20.00, respectively.
In the New England Power Pool (NEPOOL), peak, non-firm electricity prices for Tuesday was pegged $29.25-$29.75 at Northeast Utilities's territory border, up from Friday's assessment of $27.25-$27.75.
